I have always thought this background is too dark in day mode:

pasted image
@Steve Howell I have always thought it is a bad idea to highlight the whole block
It's more subtle in night mode, which I think we should emulate in day mode. (Some people like me just can't make the jump to night mode--it looks nice, but I just prefer day mode.)

Steve Howell I have always thought it is a bad idea to highlight the whole block

I totally agree. I don't think we can win that argument, but I think we can get buy-in for a better color.

@Rishi Gupta I know already poked you on this, but we were dealing with some bigger issues at the time. Now that the hover changes have been merged, do you have time to consider a slightly better background color for day mode?
I guess I'm not convinced yet the current one is bad? I think it has roughly the right visual weight.
I feel itâ€™s way too strong. And Boris seems to agree. Its only purpose is to show grouping, correct?

Here are a few sample images that may change your mind :slight_smile:
Here's a more clear view of how our eyes move around the page. Clearly the currently selected sub menu doesn't need to be the 2nd thing your eye is distracted by:
Screen-Shot-2019-03-15-at-11.02.38-PM.png

Here's how it could look better:
Screen-Shot-2019-03-15-at-11.02.06-PM.png

@Armaan Ahluwalia I agree on both points. I like how your blurry image illustrates how distracting the color is. And I like your color choice to fix this--it's way more subtle, but it still accomplishes the goal of showing that the elements are grouped together.
Did you tweak the color or just tone down the opacity?
Just tweaked the colours a bit ( similar to what I had done for unread counts which you guys rejected haha )
Can you submit a PR for this or just post the patch here? I'll try my best on this issue to advocate for the better styling here. I personally think it's a clear improvement.

Should be trivial to replicate in a PR ( just eyedrop from the picture with the browsers eyedropper in the elements panel ). My history of getting design PRs merged is pretty poor so I'd rather someone with more credibility put in the PR.
Can't you just at least tell us what color you used? (I understand your frustration.)

Lol sure :slight_smile: 

Header: #e6eaf1
Sub-Items: #f5f6f7
@Rishi Gupta Can you look at #11911? I made an even more minimal change than Armaan proposes--I literally just tweaked the L component.
update: The build is passing on #11911.

I think we agree the highlight is prominent, and what the change would be if we wanted to make it less so. Two thoughts are:

  • I think being in a stream interleaved view is something we're hoping to make less common, so if we're choosing one color I would want it to be the right color in the topic narrow case
  • I do think we want the highlight to be pretty prominent, and visible at a glance

I think we are using the background color way too often for things that don't have to be so.
I am not arguing against actually showing the information somehow that this color represents, jus that the background is often (always?) the wrong choice.
For example, I think highlighting the stream and all topics is too much regardless of the specific background color.
I also think the different coloring of PM messages is way, way too much.
And I'd say, related to this is a pattern that is not used often in modern UI design (or has been used ever) that we do use a bit too widely - transparency.

I am against the style itself, but also against using this same style for several different purposes.
The only thing that it seems to mean is 'these things aren't like these other things'

At any point we have:

  • semi-transparent streams
  • semi-transparent messages
  • semi-transparent users
Some of these are in different state of transparency (or non-prominentness, not sure if all of them are actually transparent)
I get the purpose of the background here. I literally am asking to tone it down by a couple degrees of lightness. Which we have already done in night mode.
I get the purpose too. And argue that the UI heavines that it adds is not the right thing to do. For example, click the 'more topics' and now almost all of your sidebar is colored in this hightlight.

The more I use the mobile app the more I appreciate lack of background effects. I will concede that I am not a random user, so I donâ€™t need background colors to plausibly infer stuff. But itâ€™s just so much nicer and visually appealing to not have my eyes bombarded with random background colors.
Mobile does have the pink background for mentions. I canâ€™t find other examples.

hm, I do agree that the "more topics" highlight doesn't make sense, though I think we can just remove it from that view.
I'm open to non-highlight solutions, I just haven't seen any. E.g. slack, front, and gmail all use a highlight.
Can you send a screenshot where itâ€™s used effectively?
just as historical context: the differing color of PMs is due to wanting them to stand out in the All messages view

here's one from slack:
pasted image

(though I think that's an old screenshot; currently it's blue and even brighter)
Do you have examples of backgrounds that are more akin to the proximal issue here? (Interleaved streams)
I guess the proposal though is to use the current color for topic narrow highlight, and a different color for block highlight?
Yes
I donâ€™t oppose background colors for single rows. I actually prefer more prominence for those.
ok, I think I misunderstood. I can play around with it.
Sounds good.

I think itâ€™s a bit dangerous to get into overly philosophical discussions about this. Slack has that ugly purplish brown sidebar color, but it actually works somehow in the context of their overall design.
For this Zulip issue I literally just wanna tweak one color that several people agree is just a bit too dark.

I guess there is a current sidebar experiment in progress (changing topic hover to not be underlined, etc). If we're good with that change, we can rethink the colors on the left sidebar more generally, since the current colors were chosen to satisfy some constraints that may no longer apply.
I'm fine with the idea of making it lighter, but we should probably serialize it with the on-hover change
(mainly because I think having multiple L values is not going to look good at this level of saturation)
(so if we're going to go this route, I think we'll likely have to do what Armaan suggested above and make everything a bit greyer)

I think a single highlight can be prominent and it works well.
What does look like busyness is when we highlight too many elements.
When everything is emphasized, nothing is.
For example GMail - the highlight on hover is very light and grayish, when selected it is prominent.
In fact, we can have highlights colored in the stream's color.

I guess there is a current sidebar experiment in progress (changing topic hover to not be underlined, etc). If we're good with that change, we can rethink the colors on the left sidebar more generally, since the current colors were chosen to satisfy some constraints that may no longer apply.

The hover changes are already on czo.

When everything is emphasized, nothing is.

:thumbs_up:

(so if we're going to go this route, I think we'll likely have to do what Armaan suggested above and make everything a bit greyer)

@Rishi Gupta I liked Armaan's changes. There was a somewhat spurious change to the hue, which I didn't use. He changed the saturation, which I support, but I was trying to minimize the impact. And then he also changed the lightness, which I felt was the most impactful but non-invasive change (I know that sounds funny, but it was), so I pushed that in the PR.

I'm not an expert in color science, but I can grok the basic HSL equation:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HSL_and_HSV
The current hue for the interleaved-stream background is 202, which is fine--it's basically blue-green, which is consistent with Zulip's generally "aqua" branding.

I'm not completely clear on how saturation vs. lightness works in terms of user perception, but lightness is pretty easy to tweak in day mode (or night mode, for that matter), and it makes a difference.

Going back to #11911, all I did was tweak the lightness by 4%. If 4% is too extreme, I would propose a 2% tweak, try it out here, and see if we get any pushback. (It's a little tricky to get data here, since the premise of the background is that newbies can grok interleaved streams, which is really hard to measure, but we can treat feedback with a grain of salt.)
